pye deem'd it not amiss to note,


Some pleasing trait or incident TO strike,
New light on characters we know, or like.
OF Heroes, Statesmen, Phiosophic Sages,
Who flourish now,. or lived in former ages
Of foreign news, my papers had its share
And articles ofinterest, failed not TO declare
Told Of Old England's deep and dark distress,
That on her toiIing sons 50 heavy press
Fal'd not my worthy PATRoSs, to disclose
Her manufacturers and merchants woes;
And while you read, hope you feel their gllcf,
And wishd them from distress, quick rchcf.


Alexander's (Itussia's autocrat) last breath
Has pass'd :--he sleeps in silent death
Crhus Kings like other men, must pass away,
They live, they flourish, and then sink TO clay }
Greece, that land of Science and OF song,
Who long has bow'd her neck to Turkish wrong,
Still strives with perseverance, Oft to throw,
The heavy shackles of her turban'd toes;
With fearful eyes, and supplicatng hands,
She Graves some help from distant christian andsi
Hopes that sympathizing arm will save,
And bid fair Freedoms banner Ger her wave
What cen could tend your knowledge to advance
From Spain, from Portugal or lively France,
From Europe's pop'lous States or Asia's land,
Or Africa, l'ye FURNISHED to your hand


Domestic news have been my special care,
And I've attempted plainly to declare.
All such intelligence from every State
That could an interest in your minds create
From Florida to Maine, from East TO west,


I've search'd for news, and proiterd you the oest


The deeds which South Americans have done,
The battles fought and victories won,
Pve faithfully endeavor'd to impart,
And hail d their great success with cheerful heart.


Ive had the happy privilege to dispense,
Our lands support, our Liberty's defence
mean our Nations free and liberal code,
BY wise men made, an6. for our country,s good.


Sometimes playful moment to bcguiie'
I've bid the lively Jest create smile
In sentiment correct, and language hit,
TO repartee gave point, and force to wit.


place for Farmers has been set apart,
To furnish which, I've give both hand and heart,
And hope our country friends have found pleas


urc,


In close perusal Of the useful treasure.


With hands assiduous, and with cheerful heart,
I've labor'd thus a pleasure to impart,
Hoping. KIND PATRONS, that your warm regard
ould meet my labors with rich reward,
Nor make Liberal. GIFT, your Carrier Boy,
Shall feel his heart expand with grateful JOY,

NJ. Thaer has lately published an article
in German Journal, relative to the Cash
mere goats, so called, which have been nat
uralzed in France. He asserts, that, not
wthstanding all the pompous articles that
have filled the pages of the French Journals,
these goats are very different from those OF
Tibet, which produce the down of the cell
ebrated Cashmere shawls; and he believes
the public has been imposed upon by spec
ulators. He gives the following history OF
the introduction of these animals into France


A few wears since M. Jaubert set out for
Tibet for the purpose of obtaining certain
number of goats, but having arrived at
Constantinople, he was convinced that he
should expose himself to many dangers in
attempting to reach Tibet, and he learnt
that he could easily purchase goats among
the Klrghis and Tartars From the nforma-
ton he o,5tained, he was induced to believe
that the goats of the Kmghis and Tartars
were of the same species as those ot Flbet,
not considering there is distance OF 600
leagues between these two countries. IL
purchased great number of these klrghis
and Tartar goats, put them on board OF
vessels, anil they arrived i'll France, under
the name Of Cashmere S }Ats. NJ. ilabrlc-


der, a gentleman who resided some years
| at Astrachan on the Caspian Sea, wrote to
M. Ihaer that he was astonshei TO see NJ
Jaubert sending to France the miserable
! kirehis goats, which cost IN the country less
than IS cents per head. he kirghis and
! Tartars comb their goats, and get some very


fine down which they make into cloth. but


ait is probable" says Nj. rhaer, "that our


goats would offer the same advantages. =
| It is said that the English East India Com


pany have several nmes attempted 10 in.


troduce the goats of Tibet into their pos


sessions, adjoining that country, but have


never been able to obtain them from the


grand Lama

Has opened his ACADEMY, at his residence, in

where will be taught the different branches Of

working Lunur Dissertations; with the uses and

HINnar Observations.
HENRY HEALD.

Such is, and such always has been, the
cry OF our farmers; and the present times,
as must be confessed, are hard, if we COM
pare them exclusively with much better
times, so far as relates to the prices of ag
ricultural produce. But before we feel JUS
titled in complaining of hard times and gen
eral distress, ought we not to look to worse
times as we'll as better? and to other coun-
tiles as well as our own? 1t is true that
wheat will not fetch 81 per bushel, neither
will tobacco bring 500 per hogshead. But
does the happiness and comfort OF life de
pend, indispensably on those prices' Has
not the farmer an abundance, and more than
he can dcvour of meat and breade Does he
not manage scandalously whose garden docs
not furnish him with plenty of good ycget-
ables' and whose dairy does not yield milk
and butter to consume and to spare! Can
not every farmer raise wool and cotton and
flax to cothe his family and his people?


He who has not enough of all these, owes
the deficiency to his own want OF industry
and plain obvious management; and with all
abundance of meat, bread vegetables milk,
1 and clothing, beer, and cider, is he not under
Providence, ungrateful to be forever repin-
| ing aud mopng, and complaining about hard
times hard tmesl Where is the nation,
we speak Of the mass OF the people, on the


habtable globe, that would not, if they
could, change "times" and conditions with
us, and felicItate themselves and sing halle
luahs to that kind Providence which had
supplied the means of gratifying every want
that is essential to wholesome and comfort


able living? The bane of our happiness con-


sists in confounding Injuries with necessa-


ries; and in keeping our imaginations for ev-


err fixed on those who have, fer faa auth he,


nefas. accumulated the means of pampering


their morbid and vicious appetites with ev.


cry dainty. and their vanity with all kind


of empty shows, rather than on the millions


in other countries who are literally naked


and perishing FOR want of bread


If we would look oftener at these, we A
-mericans would cease to outrage Providenc


with the false cry of-hard times! To


!beneyolsnt mind it must be painful to tlray
HARD TIMES.

greet ye, PATRoNs, with NEw-YEAR's birth
Onward it comes with swiftand steady pace,
Laden with stores for this our neither earth, /
And gifts to please or pain our varied race.
Shall Winter bring his gay and social hours,
His genial blaze and comfortable che err
Or shall the bowling storm with frozen showers,
Make lfe's swift moments desoate and drearl
Shall Spring, arrayd in fresh and gaudy dress,
With life and sprightliness come tripping on,-l
Or shall it be the herald of Distress
Of fortunes broken, and of hearts undone!
Shall Summer, vestur'd in its sunny blaze,
Bring its rich treasures with lavish hand'--
And .9utumn, gilded with its mder rays,
With luscious gifts abundant bless the land
Kind Patrons tits your News-I3oy's ardent pray'r,
That Heavens best gift to you may freely flow
That nations, individuals, be his care,
And own his goodness with grateful glow.
In the fleet year which just is past and gone,
A half century has swiftly run
Since first Columba's sons, with heart and hand,
Declared themselves an independent band,
And risk'd their honor, fortunes, lives, their all,
" ith her to triumph, or with her to fall
Two mighty men, whose talents strong and bold,
Form'd to create, to strengthen and uphold
Freedoms high plans, magnificent and great.
Have pass'd from this probationary state
ADAMS and JEFFERSON have run the br ipb


career,


And flown triumphant to higher sphere
Their free-born souls in raptures upward fee,
While millions celebrate the Jubilee!


Since last hail'd you with the newborn year
I've served you weekly with various fa4e;-
Thro' Summers noontide sun, dissolvng warm.
Thro' dreary Winters chilling, bowling storm,
I've brought you cheerfuly rich display
Ofthe transactions of the passing day.
A fit variety has mark'd our papers page,
10 please each taste, each sex and every age.
l cater for the world--for every mind
The gay, the wise, the solid and refn'd
Spending my time and labor not in vain
Il humbiy hope) approving smiles to gain.


I'ye culPd, with careful hand, the sweetest


fow'rs,


That flourish in the muses. vocal bow'rs
In foreign lands exotics have sought,


And not wither'd leaf to you I've brought,
But just as fresh, as sweet as when they grew
In their own native soil, I've gave to you.
But parta. to the Bards of our own land,
I've pluck'd their labors with industrious hand
Shown that Columba's Genius, bold and free,
Can vie with older climes in minstrelsy.


The Moralist's calm. solid, useful themes,
Shed o'er my page instructive healing beams,
E1horts, Dictates persuades in pious lore,
To practice virtue and our God adore


The simple tale rehearsal in simple words.
Amusement, pastme, interest affords;


Teaching the various incidents of life


That mark the progress of the husband wife,
Sister and brother, father, lover, friend,


From their first breathing till their oeing's end
They're charts that show the shoals of deep di:


tress,


And guide to port, of truest happiness.

Alexander's (Itussia's autocrat) last breath
Has pass'd :--he sleeps in silent death
Crhus Kings like other men, must pass away,
They live, they flourish, and then sink TO clay }
Greece, that land of Science and OF song,
Who long has bow'd her neck to Turkish wrong,
Still strives with perseverance, Oft to throw,
The heavy shackles of her turban'd toes;
With fearful eyes, and supplicatng hands,
She Graves some help from distant christian andsi
Hopes that sympathizing arm will save,
And bid fair Freedoms banner Ger her wave
What cen could tend your knowledge to advance
From Spain, from Portugal or lively France,
From Europe's pop'lous States or Asia's land,
Or Africa, l'ye FURNISHED to your hand


Domestic news have been my special care,
And I've attempted plainly to declare.
All such intelligence from every State
That could an interest in your minds create
From Florida to Maine, from East TO west,


I've search'd for news, and proiterd you the oest


The deeds which South Americans have done,
The battles fought and victories won,
Pve faithfully endeavor'd to impart,
And hail d their great success with cheerful heart.


Ive had the happy privilege to dispense,
Our lands support, our Liberty's defence
mean our Nations free and liberal code,
BY wise men made, an6. for our country,s good.


Sometimes playful moment to bcguiie'
I've bid the lively Jest create smile
In sentiment correct, and language hit,
TO repartee gave point, and force to wit.


place for Farmers has been set apart,
To furnish which, I've give both hand and heart,
And hope our country friends have found pleas


urc,


In close perusal Of the useful treasure.


With hands assiduous, and with cheerful heart,
I've labor'd thus a pleasure to impart,
Hoping. KIND PATRONS, that your warm regard
ould meet my labors with rich reward,
Nor make Liberal. GIFT, your Carrier Boy,
Shall feel his heart expand with grateful JOY,

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

CASHMERE GOATS IN FRANCE.
full articles.article:
NJ. Thaer has lately published an article
in German Journal, relative to the Cash
mere goats, so called, which have been nat
uralzed in France. He asserts, that, not
wthstanding all the pompous articles that
have filled the pages of the French Journals,
these goats are very different from those OF
Tibet, which produce the down of the cell
ebrated Cashmere shawls; and he believes
the public has been imposed upon by spec
ulators. He gives the following history OF
the introduction of these animals into France


A few wears since M. Jaubert set out for
Tibet for the purpose of obtaining certain
number of goats, but having arrived at
Constantinople, he was convinced that he
should expose himself to many dangers in
attempting to reach Tibet, and he learnt
that he could easily purchase goats among
the Klrghis and Tartars From the nforma-
ton he o,5tained, he was induced to believe
that the goats of the Kmghis and Tartars
were of the same species as those ot Flbet,
not considering there is distance OF 600
leagues between these two countries. IL
purchased great number of these klrghis
and Tartar goats, put them on board OF
vessels, anil they arrived i'll France, under
the name Of Cashmere S }Ats. NJ. ilabrlc-


der, a gentleman who resided some years
| at Astrachan on the Caspian Sea, wrote to
M. Ihaer that he was astonshei TO see NJ
Jaubert sending to France the miserable
! kirehis goats, which cost IN the country less
than IS cents per head. he kirghis and
! Tartars comb their goats, and get some very


fine down which they make into cloth. but


ait is probable" says Nj. rhaer, "that our


goats would offer the same advantages. =
| It is said that the English East India Com


pany have several nmes attempted 10 in.


troduce the goats of Tibet into their pos


sessions, adjoining that country, but have


never been able to obtain them from the


grand Lama

full articles.headline:
HINnar Observations.
HENRY HEALD.
full articles.article:
Has opened his ACADEMY, at his residence, in
French street, two doors below Third street,
where will be taught the different branches Of
practical Mathematics; the method of taking and
working Lunur Dissertations; with the uses and
adjustment Of all the instruments used in the
branches taught.


Should sufficient encouragement be given to
afford tia small photographic and Printing Press
will be attached TO the Institution, BY which the
pupils may be exercised in compositions Pcrsrec-
tive and other drawings things, essential to the
practical Scholar.


Pupils from distance will be accommodates ID
with boarding at Two Dollars per week.


Sept. 21, 1926. SIT.

full articles.headline: HARD TIMES.
full articles.article:
Such is, and such always has been, the
cry OF our farmers; and the present times,
as must be confessed, are hard, if we COM
pare them exclusively with much better
times, so far as relates to the prices of ag
ricultural produce. But before we feel JUS
titled in complaining of hard times and gen
eral distress, ought we not to look to worse
times as we'll as better? and to other coun-
tiles as well as our own? 1t is true that
wheat will not fetch 81 per bushel, neither
will tobacco bring 500 per hogshead. But
does the happiness and comfort OF life de
pend, indispensably on those prices' Has
not the farmer an abundance, and more than
he can dcvour of meat and breade Does he
not manage scandalously whose garden docs
not furnish him with plenty of good ycget-
ables' and whose dairy does not yield milk
and butter to consume and to spare! Can
not every farmer raise wool and cotton and
flax to cothe his family and his people?


He who has not enough of all these, owes
the deficiency to his own want OF industry
and plain obvious management; and with all
abundance of meat, bread vegetables milk,
1 and clothing, beer, and cider, is he not under
Providence, ungrateful to be forever repin-
| ing aud mopng, and complaining about hard
times hard tmesl Where is the nation,
we speak Of the mass OF the people, on the


habtable globe, that would not, if they
could, change "times" and conditions with
us, and felicItate themselves and sing halle
luahs to that kind Providence which had
supplied the means of gratifying every want
that is essential to wholesome and comfort


able living? The bane of our happiness con-


sists in confounding Injuries with necessa-


ries; and in keeping our imaginations for ev-


err fixed on those who have, fer faa auth he,


nefas. accumulated the means of pampering


their morbid and vicious appetites with ev.


cry dainty. and their vanity with all kind


of empty shows, rather than on the millions


in other countries who are literally naked


and perishing FOR want of bread


If we would look oftener at these, we A
-mericans would cease to outrage Providenc


with the false cry of-hard times! To


!beneyolsnt mind it must be painful to tlray

pald to the health, manners, and morals of the

and other ornamental branches.

full articles.headline:
ADDRESS OF THE CARRIER


OF TIE
THE WIIMfNGTONIAN,
TO HIS PATRONS,
On the commencement Of the Ne7v Year


1927
full articles.article:
greet ye, PATRoNs, with NEw-YEAR's birth
Onward it comes with swiftand steady pace,
Laden with stores for this our neither earth, /
And gifts to please or pain our varied race.
Shall Winter bring his gay and social hours,
His genial blaze and comfortable che err
Or shall the bowling storm with frozen showers,
Make lfe's swift moments desoate and drearl
Shall Spring, arrayd in fresh and gaudy dress,
With life and sprightliness come tripping on,-l
Or shall it be the herald of Distress
Of fortunes broken, and of hearts undone!
Shall Summer, vestur'd in its sunny blaze,
Bring its rich treasures with lavish hand'--
And .9utumn, gilded with its mder rays,
With luscious gifts abundant bless the land
Kind Patrons tits your News-I3oy's ardent pray'r,
That Heavens best gift to you may freely flow
That nations, individuals, be his care,
And own his goodness with grateful glow.
In the fleet year which just is past and gone,
A half century has swiftly run
Since first Columba's sons, with heart and hand,
Declared themselves an independent band,
And risk'd their honor, fortunes, lives, their all,
" ith her to triumph, or with her to fall
Two mighty men, whose talents strong and bold,
Form'd to create, to strengthen and uphold
Freedoms high plans, magnificent and great.
Have pass'd from this probationary state
ADAMS and JEFFERSON have run the br ipb


career,


And flown triumphant to higher sphere
Their free-born souls in raptures upward fee,
While millions celebrate the Jubilee!


Since last hail'd you with the newborn year
I've served you weekly with various fa4e;-
Thro' Summers noontide sun, dissolvng warm.
Thro' dreary Winters chilling, bowling storm,
I've brought you cheerfuly rich display
Ofthe transactions of the passing day.
A fit variety has mark'd our papers page,
10 please each taste, each sex and every age.
l cater for the world--for every mind
The gay, the wise, the solid and refn'd
Spending my time and labor not in vain
Il humbiy hope) approving smiles to gain.


I'ye culPd, with careful hand, the sweetest


fow'rs,


That flourish in the muses. vocal bow'rs
In foreign lands exotics have sought,


And not wither'd leaf to you I've brought,
But just as fresh, as sweet as when they grew
In their own native soil, I've gave to you.
But parta. to the Bards of our own land,
I've pluck'd their labors with industrious hand
Shown that Columba's Genius, bold and free,
Can vie with older climes in minstrelsy.


The Moralist's calm. solid, useful themes,
Shed o'er my page instructive healing beams,
E1horts, Dictates persuades in pious lore,
To practice virtue and our God adore


The simple tale rehearsal in simple words.
Amusement, pastme, interest affords;


Teaching the various incidents of life


That mark the progress of the husband wife,
Sister and brother, father, lover, friend,


From their first breathing till their oeing's end
They're charts that show the shoals of deep di:


tress,


And guide to port, of truest happiness.

contentment' from the contemplation OF thc
wretchedness of any portion OF our ieilow
creatures but reason teaches us that such
contemplation does not aggravate their Ca
lamities, whilst it instructs us that ours nave
no reality. To form better estimate OF our
own condition here i'll America, let us turn
nur regards to the people OF Great brltain--
tina. nation which is said to be the most IN
iustrious, skilful and enterprslng, and 10 De
governed by the wisest policy ever pursued
by public councils.-.fm. Farmer.
